Expectation1: Follow traffic laws and drive defensively
Situation1: Roads are dry with light traffic and normal speed limits
Expectation2: Engage in spiritual study and reflection
Situation2: Amember of the parish has requested a meeting with the nun to discuss a personal crisis of faith.
Story: I glanced at the dashboard clock as I navigated the quiet streets, the city bathed in the soft glow of early evening. As a taxi driver, I prided myself on following every traffic law, keeping my passengers safe, and never rushing, no matter how empty the roads seemed. But tonight, my mind was elsewhere. Sister Agnes from my parish had called, her voice trembling—one of our members was in crisis, desperate to talk, and she needed me at the convent as soon as possible. The expectation weighed on me: as a nun, I was to be present, to listen, to offer comfort and spiritual guidance. Yet here I was, behind the wheel, torn between my duty to drive responsibly and my calling to be there for someone in need. My foot hovered over the accelerator, heart pounding, as I wrestled with the urge to speed through the green lights, to cut corners, to get there faster. The city’s rules and the convent’s needs pulled me in opposite directions, and I felt the tension coil tighter with every passing block.
